column3: Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>--terms of testifying. So part of what we will do today, is for you all to testify to what you know, about Furious Flower, how many ways you've entered this whole phenomenon  that's</font>
<font color='#008080'>called Furious Flower. So that's how we're going to involve all the voices in this room.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And the subtext, I think, for this workshop for this seminar is... you will teach what you know. Isn't that the, isn't that the reason we are doing this legacy? I started calling this this legacy</font>
<font color='#008080'>seminar.</font>

<font color='#008080'>Because if we learn about Sonia Sanchez's work, and we are comfortable with it -- we appreciate it -- we will teach it. The reason Sonia in 1965, had to mimeograph Black authors is that there were no</font>
<font color='#008080'>texts for these authors when she taught at San Francisco State.</font>

<font color='#008080'>I've heard you tell that story many times. And um, but, she realized when she started, that these authors must be taught. And the only way that they were going to be taught is that she was going to</font>
<font color='#008080'>teach them. And then she realized that if she didn't start a Black Studies program, that when she left, it would be like a black hole again.</font>
<font color='#008080'>So, I really believe that you teach what you know. And when I came to James Madison University, in 1985, I was the first African American to be hired in the department.</font>

<font color='#008080'>Now, I didn't learn until later that there was great resentment about my hiring. And Azadi, you had a, a laugh of recognition there. It's like you had a little white handkerchief and you said: I know</font>
<font color='#008080'>what you talkin about.</font>
<font color='#008080'>And that's how it was, for so many Black women and men coming into academe in the late '70s and '80s. In fact, I was sharing with Sonia and Azadi and Becky at lunch,</font>

<font color='#008080'>that when my first departmental meeting, and I'd been I was at JMU for just a week, maybe two weeks at the most. I go into the meeting, and I get there early, so that people will know that I'm going</font>
<font color='#008080'>to be a functioning part of this department.</font>

<font color='#008080'>So I come in and take my seat in the second to the last row. And in comes this man, my colleagues, smelling of cigarette smoke, and bourbon. He just happened to be the Southern Literature specialist.</font>

<font color='#008080'>I'll never forget his name, David Hallman. I'll put it out there. I'll put it out there, because, you know, let's call a spade a spade. So I'm sitting there waiting for the meeting to begin. He comes</font>
<font color='#008080'>in trailing faculty members.</font>
<font color='#008080'>And he comes and sits behind me. And he says to them, "come on back here to the Jim Crow section."</font>
DaMaris B. Hill
<font color='darkcyan'>Say What year it was again.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>That was 1985 DaMaris. Come on back in the Jim Crow section. So I, I was there as a Commonwealth visiting professor, my husband and I were deciding whether we were going to stay. So</font>
<font color='#008080'>we had a year to decide and I'm now here for only two weeks. My husband's having a great experience.</font>

<font color='#008080'>So I bit my lip and I said, oh my god, what have I come into? ...Well... the meeting was about to begin. And other people were coming in, just as you all were just coming in. And then he said to them,</font>
<font color='#008080'>beckoning, "come on back here with us niggas".</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Oh, no he didn't.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>So no, that's documented in this book, Shaping Memories. Because I wanted people to understand what we had to go through as women in academe.</font>

<font color='#008080'>So that was my first week at James Madison University. Now, obviously, things have gotten better. But that was my introduction, and why, why was this man allowed to do this? And do you know, how do</font>
<font color='#008080'>you think people responded? I didn't think I was gonna get off on this, but how do you think people responded?</font>
Class
<font color='cyan'>They were quiet.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>They were quiet. No one said a word.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Cause you didn't, thats right.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>What? No one said a word. Well, when he said that, to me, my stomach started churning. And I said, if I don't respond immediately to this, that I did not hold my head up in this</font>
<font color='#008080'>faculty or at this school.</font>

<font color='#008080'>So I cornered him, I stood up, the head of the department, nobody said a thing. And I said to him... If you say anything like that to me again, in my presence, you're not only gonna need a lawyer,</font>
<font color='#008080'>you're gonna need a doctor.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And I meant it. Because I was really, really sure that it was going to be physical. If I had to deal with this again. And the thing that made me angry, I have been, since I've been a teacher, and I</font>
<font color='#008080'>have been a teacher since 1971, I have been a fierce advocate for my students.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And I thought, if this man who is honored by his colleagues, has this kind of latitude with a colleague, someone who's a peer, what is he doing inside the classroom with students? So that, it made me</font>
<font color='#008080'>fighting, fighting mad.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And Becky asked, Who are the Wintergreen Women? Well, the reason that we started, that I started Wintergreen, was I knew that if I faced that, coming up, into James Madison University, that Nikki</font>
<font color='#008080'>Giovanni, even though certainly her reputation far exceeded mine,</font>

<font color='#008080'>but human nature is human nature, she was going to Virginia Tech. So I said, let me gather around her some women who will have her back for the few years, I thought she might be there two years. For</font>
<font color='#008080'>the few years that she will be at Virginia Tech.</font>
<font color='#008080'>So I call Darrell Dance. Your mentor. I called, and Darrell Dance called Opal Moore.</font>
Opal Moore
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>No she didn't.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Who did? Who did it?</font>
Opal Moore
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>I received a letter from you.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>You received a letter from me, That's right, all right, Yeah. Well, how do we get to the or-, but this is what I'm talking about. The subtext. You teach what you know. And so this is</font>
<font color='#008080'>the reason for this particular workshop. I want you all as teachers to use Furious Flower as a resource.</font>

<font color='#008080'>You know and I just started thinking this looks like an Amway. This looks like an Amway for um, What do you call it, a Tupperware you know, I'm giving you the pitch. But so how does this testifying</font>
<font color='#008080'>come into play?</font>

<font color='#008080'>I'm going to walk you through some of the major events and the history of Furious Flower. And I want you to put up your hand if you have anything to add. If you somehow had some connection with this</font>
<font color='#008080'>activity, I want you to testify to that.</font>
<font color='#008080'>And so that you will go out and you will be ambassadors for Furious Flower.</font>

<font color='#008080'>Already, people are telling me that Furious Flower has not only taken on the, I suppose the heft of an institution, but it's taken on the aura of a kind of movement. We sort of started something,</font>
<font color='#008080'>and you all are part of it, you're part of that history now. You you, you are a part of Furious Flower. And we want to start in 1994. The first Furious Flower conference.</font>

<font color='#008080'>What is interesting, just recently, we have digitized the entire conference. So you can go, and you can go to any one of these thumbnails. And you can see what happened at that historic conference.</font>
<font color='#008080'>I had the foresight to have videotaped almost every session. And you can see I've changed a little bit, alright. Hands different.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Dimples are still there, yeah, all right. Let's see if we can, let's see who we might wanna hear a little bit of.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>The dimple's still there.</font>
DaMaris B. Hill
<font color='darkcyan'>Let's hear Ethelbert.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>A little Ethelbert? Where's Ethelbert?</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>To the right there</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Alright. Alright, good. Let's click on it.</font>

<font color='#008080'>All right well, we just don't want technical difficulties. No matter. But, so, if you go online, you will be able to hear Ethelbert, and Sonia, and all of the 35 poets who were part of that particular</font>
<font color='#008080'>conference.</font>
Speaker Unknown

<font color='NONE'>I remember that conference, I walked around with my big sign, I asked somebody for one of the signs and I finally got it, and I walked to every single person, including you, and Sonia</font>
<font color='NONE'>Sanchez and asked you all to sign my poster, I mean I was asking all the poets, and um, I still have that poster.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>That poster, you still have that poster, that poster is worth a lot of money. Yeah. It was, now, um, who knows why we did the Furious Flower conference in the first place. Does</font>
<font color='#008080'>anyone have a knowledge of that?</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>[inaudible]... to celebrate Gwen Brooks?</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>Yes, that's exactly right. In 1993, a year before the conference materialized. Gwen Brooks came to Virginia. And this was her second visit to Virginia during my time here,</font>

<font color='#008080'>I always said, from the time that I went to Roosevelt University to teach, that I would invite Gwendolyn Brooks to every school that I taught at. And I did that because, when I got to Roosevelt</font>
<font color='#008080'>University in Chicago, my very first teaching gig,</font>
<font color='#008080'>one of my colleagues told me that, you know, we could have had Gwendolyn Brooks here. But the faculty turned her down. And I said, What?</font>

<font color='#008080'>This was in 1971. I am green, out of the University of Chicago with a Master's degree. Gwendolyn Brooks, in 1950, when I was four years old, had gotten a Pulitzer Prize for poetry... and she couldn't</font>
<font color='#008080'>teach at Roosevelt University?</font>

<font color='#008080'>You have to know the story of how we have broken down walls. So you can appreciate where you are now, but also have the honor to go on and get in there and fight for your students. So she came to</font>
<font color='#008080'>James Madison in 1986. And she came back to the area in 1993.</font>

<font color='#008080'>When she came back, I said, to Gwen, I said, Gwen, you're gonna have to come over to JMU, again, and speak, she says, Well, I was just here. She said, I won't come this year, but I'll come next year.</font>
<font color='#008080'>So I had a whole year to plan for her reading, which was going to be just the reading.</font>

<font color='#008080'>I started telling people, you know, Gwendolyn Brooks is coming to campus, would you like to come and be there with her while she reads? And they said, you know, we not only want to be there, but we</font>
<font color='#008080'>want to honor her by reading with her. And so what started with one reader, ended up being, what, 35 invited poets, and then another 50 or so just came.</font>
And so that was 1994. So Furious Flower, gets its title from Gwendolyn Brooks' poem, Second Sermon on the Warpland. And the line's: "The time/ cracks into furious flower. Lifts it's face/ all
<font color='#008080'>unashamed. And sways in wicked grace."</font>

<font color='#008080'>So by the time I started trying to come up with a title for this gathering, it was now about more than Gwendolyn Brooks. Furious Flower was Gwendolyn Brooks. But it was also the period that she was a</font>
<font color='#008080'>part of. It was the period from 1950, forward.</font>
<font color='#008080'>And so these were the poets that came out in large numbers to help honor her. And it was just a magnificent, magnificent conf- I never expected to do it again.</font>

<font color='#008080'>In fact, I called my friend Sonia, and I said, Sonia I have all of these people talking about, (after it was over), talking about you have to do that again, that was wonderful. And that was about</font>
<font color='#008080'>three or four years in. And so Sonia said to me, she said, Well you know, something this big, you can't do it every five years. You gotta wait, you remember?</font>
Sonia Sanchez
<font color='navy'>Oh yeah.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Yeah.</font>
Sonia Sanchez
<font color='navy'>You wanted to do it right away, actually.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>And so I didn't, I didn't do it. And then some of the younger poets started saying, we heard so much about Furious Flower, when are you going to do this --</font>
Sonia Sanchez
<font color='navy'>Just like we said today, Jo.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>Yes, just like [inaudible] said last night, but when is the next one? You know, are you're going to do the next one? Well, I set a date. And so I said, After 10 years 2004. So 2004</font>
<font color='#008080'>the next Furious Flower conference happened.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And the outpouring for that conference was amazing. So we had 50 invited poets. And at each point, Sonia Sanchez was there with me to do Furious Flower. She was there to read on the opening night, on</font>
<font color='#008080'>Thursday night with Amiri Baraka. I'll never forget that night.</font>

<font color='#008080'>You can go online and see that night. You can go to the, the videos. And you can-- honestly, these are still available, at California Newsreel. If you buy them. This is what-- who testified to this</font>
<font color='#008080'>last night. Somebody said, you know about having these to have in the class, and to-</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Oh, that was me.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Yeah, today, yeah. You said that.</font>
Becky Thompson
<font color='darkolivegreen'>I'll second that emotion.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>Yeah, that's right. Okay. So those videos, I realized that a lot of schools would not have the resources, or the wherewithal to bring Sonia to their school. So if they can go and get</font>
<font color='#008080'>a clip of Sonia talking about her work, hear, her reading her poems, then that would be second best.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And so we did those videos and I love that we came up with the titles, Elders, Warriors, Seers, Initiates. Because there were four generations of poets at the first conference. At the second</font>
<font color='#008080'>conference, there were certainly at least four generations.</font>
<font color='#008080'>The second conference was dedicated to none other than Sonia Sanchez and Amiri Baraka. Does any, who remembers what happened that was controversial, at the second?</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Oh, I don't know.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Okay, go on.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Oh, I don't remember what was controvertial.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Okay, all right, go on [inaudible].</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Well, are you talking about-- I may not have this exactly right, but I think, um, Thomas Sayers Ellis got angry about a mention of Henry Louis Gates,</font>

<font color='NONE'>I think Baraka was on stage, and he said something about Gates, And some people-- it wasn't only Ellis but I was sitting near him-- some people in the audience kind of took umbrage and got noisy, and</font>
<font color='NONE'>that was one thing.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>That was one thing, and see I, there's history out there that I don't even know.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Yeah, well, I remember that one, because it was hard for Baraka to finish the reading. People were like, you know, and then people would talk in between.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Okay, alright.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>So that was one thing.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Opal.</font>
Opal Moore

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>So I got a telephone call from Joanne one morning. She was on her way to the president's office, because a group of students were organizing, reportedly organizing a protest against Amiri</font>
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>Baraka being invited to the second Furious Flower. So, Joanne, just, had to--</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Because of the poem.</font>
Opal Moore
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>Because of the poem, because of the poem he wrote, following 9/11</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
Somebody Blew up America.
Opal Moore
Somebody Blew up America. So the students, of course, I think it was, for them to do that. But what was interesting, and what I think, is powerful in the story is that Joanne, of
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>course, knew that she was not going to retract the invitation to Amiri Baraka. So that was understood.</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>But she was thinking through the ways, being both a Professor, being herself, being a poet, being a teacher, and also being a member of a variety of communities, she was thinking about the ways that</font>
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>she would make it clear that while the students' protests could take place, that Amiri Baraka would be coming.</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>So I remember that she and I, I know that you called [inaudible] before  you went to meet the president, to talk about what kind of understanding should we bring to the situation. So, so I know that</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>the controversy then was on the campus, but what was interesting was that when Amiri Baraka came and presented, there were-- I was in that audience and I noticed that certain, certain people refused</font>
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>to stand when, and participate in his standing ovation.</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>But the house stood for Amiri Baraka. I noted a number of people (of course I couldn't have known them), but I noted a number of people who sat. Very pointedly not standing. So that was a very</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>important point of contention around the right of a poet to speak, the right of Amiri Baraka to tell the story that he needed to tell, through that poem and other poems,</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>but also, the right for students to engage in a conversation and a discussion around something that they thought they needed to speak about. And then, the other part is the magazine article that</font>
<font color='darkgoldenrod'>followed, where a number of voices were published around this issue.</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>And so I think that all of these things, I mean, in terms of talking about a teaching tool, even some of the sidebar information that surrounds these kinds of conferences are very useful teaching</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>tools, just around poetry, around, around freedom of speech, around truth-telling. And, and also I would say, around doing your homework if you're gonna protest something.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>Yeah, exactly. Well, you know, I was very fortunate to have amazing mentors. And Gwendolyn Brooks was a mentor. Margaret Walker was a mentor. Sonia Sanchez, my sister, and I remember</font>
<font color='#008080'>the, the year I came to James Madison University.</font>
<font color='#008080'>I had just gotten here. And Sonia called me and she was screaming on the telephone. And she was screaming because police in Philadelphia had dropped bombs on MOVE.</font>
<font color='#008080'>And she was just saying, you know, in fact, it was it was no, it was it was just before I got here. It was in April wasn't it?</font>
Sonia Sanchez
<font color='navy'>It was in May.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>May, okay. May, okay. It was just before I came, I knew we were coming. Our furniture was already going to be moved. I was just getting ready to go to Virginia. And, you know, when</font>
<font color='#008080'>you, when something like that happens, and when you understand that authorities can make you do a lot if you are scared.</font>

<font color='#008080'>But I had such peace. I called my Wintergreen sisters, I had such peace about what I was going to do. This was just a month before the conference was supposed to happen. It was in August that this</font>
<font color='#008080'>controversy started. It was to honor Sonia and Amiri.</font>
<font color='#008080'>I made up in my mind that if the president would ask me to disinvite Amiri  Baraka, then I would call the entire conference off.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And, that would have been a rough call, but it would've been the the only call I could have made. And that's why I wanted support, I wanted to hear people talk about what they thought, but I made up</font>
<font color='#008080'>in my mind that if you have any principle, you have to stand on principle.</font>
Why? If they can ask me to disinvite Amiri Baraka, because of a poem-- Somebody Blew up America-- then they can ask me to disinvite Nicki Giovanni because of her poems, written in the 1960s, or
<font color='#008080'>Sonia's poems, or Rita Dove's poems.</font>

<font color='#008080'>If you find something that you don't like, about their political point of view, then no one is safe, and so I was not going to do that. So I was gonna make-- even though we have put in a year's worth</font>
<font color='#008080'>of work.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And so that's a sidebar. But that's an important one. It's an important one, because you in your own careers will have to make decisions that are tough decisions. And they will have to do, be based on</font>
<font color='#008080'>principles that you hold dear. And if you sell out on one principle, you'll sell out on all of them. Yeah, go on, [inaudible]</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Oh no, I'm just agreeing with you.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Oh okay, but you were putting your hand up.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>No, I'm just, you know.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>Alright. Okay. Alright well, we, you know, I can go through this really quickly, because I would love for you to get your voice in it. You know, I really, I really wanted you to do</font>
<font color='#008080'>that.</font>
<font color='#008080'>So 2004, the conference is available entirely on DVD.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>2004. The entire conference, well the  entire conference is available on, now, this MDID, which is on the website. So you can go there under most circumstances, and click on it-- I</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>2004?</font>
<font color='NONE'>don't know what's going on with this site.</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>Oh, I do.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>What?</font>
Speaker Unknown
<font color='NONE'>The guy came in here and one of, one of the JMU (I totally forgot until just now) One of the JMU employees unfortunately clicked on a virus, and so it is now in our system.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>It has a virus on it.</font>
Speaker Unknown

<font color='NONE'>And he was in here, I would like to say about 15 minutes before you came in here. Yeah, but not the person that clicked but the person trying to correct. So he may have begun to</font>
<font color='NONE'>correct but they may-- it may be something going through the system now. System wide. I'm sorry, I totally forgot.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Okay. Well, you know what, let's cut, Let's cut it off. Yeah, we can cut it off. We did see some of the pictures, and then that will get rid of that static.</font>
Speaker Unknown

<font color='NONE'>I think that it's wonderful that you've done that. I was trying to convince my school to buy, well, the first tapes. And then when I went online, and I teach strictly online, it</font>

<font color='NONE'>didn't become a pressing issue for me because it was only for my selfish needs. You know, the faculty, what they needed. But now, I can use the website as part of my class instead of directing them</font>
<font color='NONE'>right to Youtube, to find clips. It's very helpful.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin

<font color='#008080'>That's right. That's right. So those conferences are available, now on the internet, as well as from California Newsreel. In California Newsreel, you have the conversations that you</font>
<font color='#008080'>will not find between the poet's and other poets or critics, and you have their readings, which are invaluable.</font>

<font color='#008080'>So just listen to the people who are on the DVD for 2004. Sonia Sanchez, Rita Dove, Amiri Baraka, Lucille Clifton, Askia Tour??, Haki Madhubuti, just to name a few. They are, they're there. But there</font>
<font color='#008080'>were 25, there are 25 on here.</font>

<font color='#008080'>Okay, fast forward. After 2004 and that conference Linwood Rose, realized that we had something going here. And I still directed the Honors Program. Working on this, these conferences on the side, I</font>
<font color='#008080'>still had a full time job teaching my courses. But on the side, I put together these conferences.</font>

<font color='#008080'>I decided that, okay, we could have a center. And I went to him with a proposal. And he, in his infinite wisdom, decided to give us about $100,000 to start the Furious Flower Poetry Center.</font>

<font color='#008080'>As I said, things have changed. I had the support of the first President Ronald Carrier for the first conference. For the second conference, I had the support of the president, President Linwood Rose.</font>

<font color='#008080'>In fact, just a footnote, to that story about Amiri Baraka. Dr. Rose decided, if there was only one event that he was going to go to, it was going to be the reading of Amiri Baraka. And he went to</font>
<font color='#008080'>that reading, and he sent me an email afterwards and said, what was the big deal? He didn't hear anything that he was offended by.</font>

<font color='#008080'>Now talk about historical vindication. Who comes out with an entire book about what was known before 9/11? In the Congressional Record. So if we, if we silence our-- if we allow our poets to be</font>
<font color='#008080'>silenced, we will live in a very dangerous world.</font>
Sonia Sanchez
<font color='navy'>Also,</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='#008080'>Yes.</font>
Sonia Sanchez

<font color='navy'>And as an aside, if you allow the younger poets to disrespect the elder poets then there'd be danger to society and that should be noted, finally, as an aside, only as an element I'm</font>

<font color='navy'>saying it. you know, at some point, it has got to be addressed. You could disagree with what Baraka says, but you don't disrespect the elder. And I watched people, the younger poets disrespect him,</font>

<font color='navy'>You know, and I almost got up and said something, then I said no it's Joanne's, you know, it's been enough uproar here already. But send a sign as teachers, you know, and professors, that you really</font>

<font color='navy'>have got to insist, you know, at some point, that you can come on a different level of how you write and why you write and what you're about, you know, and you're not political, but-- and etcetera.</font>

<font color='navy'>But still, you know, we disagreed with some of the older poets. I mean, I know, I was, I'll never forget, and I told you about this, I got a long letter about... three letters, from different</font>
<font color='navy'>departments about people who were up for tenure. The people who wrote it knew that we were completely different politically.</font>

<font color='navy'>Now you have to hear that. And I got these letters, you know, and the calls saying we'd like you to write a recommendation, bla bla bla bla bla. And I said, certainly, so I wrote the recommendation,</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>We batten our eyes and hum/ to the below- sea- level-blues./ This land is ours bought and paid/ In our flesh and loves rended,/ In our rents, paid cash--/ We hold these beauties to be self evident/ As</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>Settle down now and wait on The Lord!/ Scheduled to arrive in four more days/ by helicopter, those chopping blades/ Troubling, troubling the waters below/ Coming, just as soooon, soon as He sniffs/</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>But that 2nd coming will be too late./ The bell's already been rung/ And Richard Baker says/ the jig is up. Yep, say the corpse/ of engineers, the party's over. Their levee broke a tooth/ and through</font>

<font color='darkgoldenrod'>Once more we march/ leave home and hearth./ There's some deep memory here--/ Once more our shores shrink/ from hungry view,/ our dead swallowed up/ by the waters.//</font>
